newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Mill owners say Karachi wheat flour crisis over.
newsitem.headline: Mill owners say Karachi wheat flour crisis over.

text.p: A flour shortage that sparked unrest in the southern port city of Karachi is almost over, the Pakistan Flour Mills Association said on Saturday.
"The markets will be flooded with flour when they reopen after Eid al-Adha holidays," Naeem Malik, the association's vice chairman, told Reuters.
The flour crisis struck Karachi ahead of a four-day holiday for the Moslem feast of Eid al-Adha, which began on Thursday.
"Some 16,000 tonnes of wheat has already arrived in Karachi from interior Sindh, while another 24,000 is due by Sunday evening," Malik said.
Karachi, the capital of Sindh province, needs about 4,000 tonnes of wheat a day to feed its estimated 12 million people.
"Flour will be available in the city, initially at slightly higher prices as farmers are selling wheat at higher rates. But the prices will gradully come down," Malik said.
Police guarded mills and bakeries earlier this week to prevent attacks by crowds of angry shoppers and looters.
"The flour shortage has dampened our Eid festivities," said Inam Khan of Orangi Town.
Flour shortages have provoked violence in several cities in recent weeks, but Karachi had previously been spared.

Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's government blames the previous caretaker administration for failing to arrange timely wheat imports, but Malik faulted the government for a ban on the movement of wheat within Pakistan and price controls.
"Now this ban has been lifted and mills can buy wheat from the interior of Sindh. The government has also promised us a share of imported wheat being unloaded at Port Qasim," he said.
Pakistan imported 1.8 million tonnes of wheat in July-March 1996/97 compared to 1.5 million in the year-ago period.
